women
Abstract: hij vragt antwoord op zijn schrijven van 30 Aug., deelt het besluit van den grooten raad over het voorstel van den koning van Pruisen mede, toont bij al het schijnbaar goede het gevaarlijke er van aan, raadt hun de overkomst van 2 of meer 
afgevaardigden uit de Zwitsersche gemeenten, om eerst het door Pruisen aangeboden land te gaan bezichtigen, krachtig te bevorderen en verhaalt omstandig, hoe hij de verschillende gevangenen gevonden heeft en bij hen grooten tegenzin tegen de kolonisatie 
naar Pruisen ducht.  11 blz. fol. met translaat 4 blz. fol.
Eng. trans. LMHS
Notes: From Eng. trans. at LMHS:
Berne, October 1, 1710
Runckel to Government
On August 30, 1710 how the situation was of the poor Mennonites who were in those countries by that time and also about the project of that was in the mind of some people with good intentions towards the Mennonites.  In order to keep these poor people in 
this country if possible in anyway, and what those with good intentions for that reason I want to receive what they a solution and declaration in order that they can take their measures for an execution of plans by them, and that they can conform 
themselves to this.  He acknowledges the receipt of a number of copies of Mennonite Confession of faith.  In order to be able to distribute those where they be needed to silence the consciences (of the opposition); for those who are prejudiced against 
these poor people and because you did not yet receive an answer on their items and according to that I do not know how to act in this matter.  I ask you for a decision in all above matters and enclose herewith copies of mentioned letters.
On the 20th of the previous month of September he presented a plan to the Government to keep them in the confines of the country.  Or the plan might not materialize, at least to give them better condition by buying their goods.  Swiss Government will free 
them for deportation to France but they don't want the Mennonites to send a deputation to King of Prussia but will retain them until they get an answer from the King.
Then they will send them at their expense to Frankfurt but the rich must go on their own.
On the other side in Prussia they will take them but their Swiss government must deport all to Frankfurt rich as well as poor, and that they must enable to sell their goods and if robbed they must investigate its whereabouts, and the Swiss government aid 
them in its return.  The Mennonites would send a Deputation but the Swiss object because Benedict Brackbill and Hans Burkie are wanted in the Deputation.  They will never grant their sending this Deputation.  To me (Runckel) it seems necessary.  For 
several reasons and especially because they can investigate themselves as to the land available and arrange all plans for their deportation thereto.  A check of 200 Rixthalers (by me) to the Mennonites, and that they could spend wisely at their own 
discretion, especially since they need clothing for the coming winter.  The day before yesterday I came so far that I could visit the prisoners in their Jails (cloisters).  I gave them consolation in their plight and I encouraged them to behave themselves 
and be quiet according to God's will and the will of the magistrates.  A certain Mr. Knost and a certain Mr. Wagner assisted him very decidely in this visiting.  In so called "Island" I found eleven men and women sitting each in an especially guarded
building but all of them without chains and "being cloistered" and among the first ones are three ill.  The men are not obliged to work but the women spin hemp and flax to pass the time.  In the alms house were sixteen men and fourteen women among 
whom are also ill and weak.  The men are altogether in one room without chains and "cloistered" and they are required to earn their bread and to card and comb their wool to do so and other work that they are capable of doing.  the women are also in a
special room but not all alone and according to that not in as close quarters (as the men).  And they as well as other women who are in the prison for several reasons must spin wool to spend their time thus.  As far as I could learn they permit them to use
their Bible and certain other books.  As I heard they have enough to eat and to drink although everthing is not too good.  Also the places where they sleep.
Among all these prisoners there are very few who had any particular property and if they had any property it is to be feared that the expenses of their imprisonment and all accompanying expenses had exhausted all resources.  Those who care for these poor 
people told me that generally among these prisoners there are not as many well to do now as amongst those who were there in the spring prior.  I spent over three hours with them and spolk with them and I learned they are willing to leave the country to 
emigrate elsewhere, but they are not fully able to forget their persecution and above all this it is to be feared that they will bring up many objections when they hear that the King of Prussia will place them in an area where people died of infectious 
sickness and pests (because of marshes), as they protested this to very strongly to me and they prayed earnestly that they would be excused from going there and rather try to settle them somewhere else, in which matter I and the above mentioned charitable 
and devoted citizens will try to do whatever is possible and will counsel together.
Futher I request you earnestly to keep me informed of all things you decide concerning the deputation to Berlin as well as of the things this deputation will talk upon and agreed upon there, as well as all things that pertain to this matter and can remedy 
the same, so that those who feel sorry for the poor Mennonites as well as St. Saphorin and me can take the necessary measures accordingly.
Greeting you heartily and commending myself to your attentive prayers and remaining in God's grace.
An humble servant to the highly respected Lord,
Joan Ludwig Rünckel

Administration - religious
Persecution - Imprisonment
Abstract: in antwoord op no. 1276; bij de onzekerheid of Bern de bedoelde landstreek bij Bourgondie zal afstaan en bij het dralen van den koning van Pruisen, verheugt hij zich, dat sommigen er over denken om de Zwitsers in Nederland te koloniseeren, hoopt 
dat de societeitsvergadering daartoe besluite en raadt dit ten allersterkste aan.  5 blz. fol.  Met translaat 3 blz. fol.
Eng. trans. LMHS
Notes: From English trans. at LMHS:
Berne November 8, 1710
Read in Council November 26, 1710
I have received your very agreeable letter of October 21st some time since and I learned therefrom to my pleasure that to you have been delivered my letters of September 30 and the 1st and 4th with enclosures and that you have pleasure in reading them.  I 
hope that my letter of October 25th also will have been handed to you, and will have been examined in like manner and that you learned about the constitution of the swamps of which a proposal has been made in the beginning and what kind of area instead of 
the prior could be proposed in order to keep the hear living good Mennonites here.
Although it is still very uncertain whether the laudable Canton of Berne can be moved to tolerate these poor folk in the country and iwll be willing to assign the move mentioned area to them and as it is very uncertain if and when the King's Majesty of 
Prussia will declare fully concerning the emigration and if the laudable Canton will agree with such declaration and finally if these people can be moved or if they can be encouraged without searing their consciences to go to a country, full of plagues and
without inhabitants and I learned also from your last letter that by some of you had been proposed whether they could not bring these from here-departing good people and place in the area of the High Magistracy and that you wanted to know my opinion 
concerning the same.  I want to inform you without any delay that this is really the best and most certain and it is most agreeable and the best to all who live here and who are willingly disposed toward these people and with whom I spoke about this in 
the great confidence and even to their hardest persecutors (as those have before hand told me) when they should bring these people under the never praised, very tolerating government of their High Magistrates and this the earlier the better.  The more 
because it is doubtful whether these good people rather prefer to go to Holland than the parts of Prussia and rather prefer to build their huts close to their brethren and fellow beleivers than among entirely strange and unkown people.
The number of these will not be so large but in the meantime I asked the Barons Knoff and Wagener, who offered themselves in the westway and to inform among the prisoners as good as possible how many they think that there are of their brethren and sisters 
in this Canton and its environs, so that we can estimate the cost and take measures accordingly.
The settling of the here living poor Mennonites in the area of the High Magistracy (of Berne) would promote the discharge of the poor prisoners and the issuing of the above mentioned proclamation of freedom would promote that mightily because they have 
decided here not to do anything in this matter before they have learned and seen the final decision of the King Majesty of Prussia whether it be agreeable or no and this stagnation would stop when they might learn that the High Magistracy is prepared to 
receive them and then let them settle in its area.  In this case they would withdraw from Prussia and try earnestly to promote this matter as well as possible to bring it to its desired completion.
I beg you to inform me by return mail what has been decided in your next meeting in this matter so that if it is thought to be good and profitable to settle them close to or amongst you, I can start working at once to bring the friends to a good end with 
the help of the Most High.  Meanwhile I need to inform you that the confessions of faith sent finally arrived and that I am distributing them and that I am regulating the matter so that if they are ready to depart this will be transpiring, better and 
sooner and I want to recommend once more to settle the here living Mennonites in the Netherlands if this is possible in any relying upon God's Grace and protection and recommending myself to your fervent prayers, always forever yours.
Your humble servant,
Johan Ludwig Runckel

Persecution - Imprisonment
Abstract: geeft bericht van den staat der zaken, verklaart de oorzaak der verbittering uit onkunde, raadt het vertalen van een doopsg. belijdenis in het Hoogduitsch en het drukken en erspreiden daarvan aan, om die onkunde weg te nemen en zendt een lijst van 
de namen der gevangenen over (De lijst ontbreekt); met translaat; 8pp. fol. (German)
Eng. Trans. LMHS
Transcription at HSP
on microfilm
Notes: From transcription at HSP:
Copie
Bern den 12tn Julii 1710
Woledle
Meine insonders hochgeehrter Herren!
Dero an mich ohne Tag und Monath abgegebenes Schreiben mit denen Beylagen habe mit worigen POst aus denen Niederlanden zurück erhalten, und darauß wie auch auß denen beygefügten pieces dero Verlangen das mehreren ersehen
Worauß in schuldiger antwort andiene, daß ob zwaren ich von Ihro hochmögenden danen herren General Staaten der in diesem Canton sich befindeten aremen Mennoniten wegen keinen fernern gnädigsten befelch empfangen, ich dannach nicht 
unterlassen mich motu proprio über den Zustand dieser armen Leuthen zu erkundigen, auch hin und wieder wo es die gelegenheit geben, Sie aufs baiste zu recommendiren Bey welchem Anlaß dann auch befunden, daß in hiesigen Regierung sich freylich 
dem Höchsten sege gedancket, noch einige Glieder befinden, welche einen moderaten Gemüths, und demnach die harte proceduren gegen diese arme Leuthe in höchsten Grad bedauern auch gegen dinselbe im recht hertzliches mitlaeyden tragen so daß 
sie ihnen wohl im beßeres geschick wünschen mögten.  Ich habe aber leyder! auch zu gleicher Zeit befunden, daß gegen ein moderates gemüth sich jeder Zeit zwey oder drey sehr praeveensirte und damnach sehr harte Gemüther herfür 
gethan, bey welchen keine remonstrationen, keine vorstellungen und keine exempel nichts verfangen wollen, auch wohl ins künftige noch verfangen dörften, es seye dann daß Gott in das Mittel trette, und ihren ihre steinerne Hertze in flißerne
Verwandeln.
Bei dieser der sachen botschaffenheit nun, welche wann sie nicht in eigener Person untersuchet, ich substan? schwerlich hätte glauben können, kann nicht sehen wonß? mann bey hiesigene Lobl. Standt zu gunsten dieser armen Leuthen, es seye durch 
einige gecommittierde, ab seyn durch requestens, recommendationen oder komst auß andere manier vor anjetzo noch werde außrichten können, zu mahlen da das point d'honneur und die reputation darzukombt und mann in solcher sach einen fehler 
geschossen zu haben durch eine öffentliche cemedie noch zur zeit nicht wird erkennen noch bekennen wollen.  Es ist zwar an nicht ehr, daß die meiste Glieder hiesiger Regierung nicht wissen waß es mit denen Mennoniten eigentlichen fuer eine 
Beschaffenheit haben, noch was zwischen ihnen und denen müntzerischen und Muensterischen Wiedertäufern für ein unterschied zu machen, sondern daß solche blinder dings alles das jenige alß evangelie glauben, was dennselben von ihr der 
Mennoniten wieder wärtigen und Verfolgern aufgebürdet? wird, und daß dannenhero noch zu hoffen daß Sie mann Ihnen etwann die Augen auff die einen oder andere weiß eröffnet werden Könnten vielleicht auf andere Gedancken gerathen 
mögten, aber ich gestehen gerne, daß bis dahero kein Mittel ausdencken können wie solches anderß zu bewerckstelligen, es seye dann, daß mann die mittel anwenden und die dieser armen Leuthen wegen herausgegebenen Schriften zu sambt der 
Mennoniten glaubens bekandnus ins hochdeutschen übersetzen, in den druck bringen und eine gute Anzahl exemplaren in hiesiger Stadt und Hand sotto mano und ins geseimts außtheilen lassen wollte, damit ein jeder en particulier seine reflexione 
darüber machen, und bey sich selbsten betrachten könne, wie weit man in Verfolgung dieser armen Leuthen fundiret.
Diesen noch und wann alles auufs genaueste bey mir halbsten überlege, so finde einmahlen daß noch zur Zeit für diese arme Leuthe kaein besseres mittel nicht übrig, als daß Sie dem ob ihren Haupter Schwebenden sehr sschweren ungewitter 
auf ein Zeitlang ausweichen und in Gottesnahmen ihren aufenthalt und eine mehrere Freiheit des Gewissens anderst wo suchen bis etwann der Zorn und Groll vergangen und mann seinen begangenen Fehler von selbsten erkennen.  Ich glaube denenhero daß das 
größte liebeswerck, so mann diesen armen Leuthen bei solcher der Sachen beschaffenheit erweisen könte wäre, wann man ihnen anderstens einen sicheren aufenthalt außfinden, und Sie aus diesem Land völlig hinweg ziehen könte.
Es haben zwarn die Fürstin von Nassau, Dietz und der Herr Graff von Neuwied sich erboten einige von solchen, fals sie Künstbar oder handwercksleuthe, anzunehmen weilen sich aber bey genauer noch forschung erfunden, daß diese Leuthe meistens 
acker und ViehLeuthe, alß dörffte solches wohl ins stecken gerathen, weilen diese herrschaften mit dergleichen Leuthe ohne denn schon übersetzet.
Dem Courantier Willem Arnold zu Amsterdam habe mit letzter POst gemeldet, daß dieser armen Leuthen wiederumb über die Zwantzig in hiesigen gefangenschaften sich befinden, auch daß die übrige miestens in die benachbarte Orth verstreuet und 
verjagt worden, denselben bittend, daß er solches meinen hochgeehrten Herren communicieren wolle.  Ich confirmiere solches himit nochmahlen, undt überstandt zu gleichen eine Verzeichnus der in hiesigen Gefängnussen sich befindenden Mennoniten 
welche mir von guther Hand communiciret worden.  Wann es immer möglich so viel trachten, mit diesen armen Gefangenen selbsten zu reden und sie in ihren Banden, so viel an mir seye wird, zu trösten.
Womit nebst allzeitigen urlaßung in Gottes starcken Gnadenschutz und Empfehlung meiner und meiner lieben Familie in hero andächtiges Gebett, stetshin bin und verbleibe
Meiner hochgeehrten HErrn Ergebenster diener
Johann Ludwig Runckel
Research Notes: <cc>LMHS--English translation
HSP--transcription</cc>

Persecution - expulsion
Persecution - Imprisonment
Abstract: de ingenieur Bodmar heeft ongunstig omtrent de moerassen geadviseerd, zoodat dit geheel moet opgegeven worden, maar medegedeeld dat er tusschen Romainmoutie en Romont, op de grenzen van Bourgondie een groote streek onbebouwd land aan Bern in 
eigendom toekomt, zoodat men dit voor de Doopsg. ter bewoning zou kunnen aanvragen; hij hoopt eerlang een kaart en raming van kosten over te zenden, bericht dat er weder eenigen zijn gevangen genomen, en verwacht dat de 100 ex. geloofsbelijdenis binnen 
weinige dagen zullen overkomen, daar zij Stuttgart reeds gepasseerd zijn.  7 blz. fol. Met translaat. 4 blz. fol.
English trans. at LMHS
Notes: From Eng. Trans. at LMHS:
October 25, 1710
I hope my letter from 4th inst. will have reached you and further too that letter I can inform you that since you told me about the difficulties of feared obstacles concerning the proposed reclamation levelling off and draining of the aforement owned 
swamps.  I have investigated carefully and I talked over everthing thoroughly with a man who is an authority (on reclamation).  If possible to make a survey of costs, which the execution of this plan might require I succeeded in finding a man by God's 
grace who is smart and devout and very charitable and hating all compulsion and oppression in matters of knowledge and he is not only an outstanding engineer but also many times is counselled by the government concerning these swamps but because this man 
does not live here in the town but six to seven hours further into the mountains viz. at Amseldingen, across Lake Thun, I went in the beginning of this week on a trip over there and I talked widely with him about the proposed plan and the mentioned 
difficulties as well as necessary expenditures.  He gave me as an answer that in his opinion according to their (Mennonite) method of livelihood in his district, it was not good to oppress and persecute the poor Taufer because of their conffesion of belief
and even worse that they chased them from their houses and lands to send them to other countries but besides he could not and did not want to counsel that they should send these good people into the proposed swamps and this for the following reasons:  1.  
because these swamps in mind do not only belong to the Canton of Berne but also the Canton of Freiburg and that these two cantons are fighting now already for almost a hundred years on the boundary dispute.....
2.  Canton of Freiburg will never sell nor exchange or cede their part of the above mentioned swamp.
3.  Because the rest of it is not the property of the Canton of Berne but belongs to the neighbor in and around those swamps who have their pastureland there during the summer.
4.  Because the River Aare in which the draining of the swamp between Aarberg and Murthenzonde.  For because the draining of a
[missing a page!]
a large portion to the displaced Waldensians, who up to this hour still use this land although they have returned to their homeland.  Besides this honest man assured me that there is wood and water sufficient that the land is good and when the woods are 
cleared, the land very adaptable to agriculture, dairying and pasturage, and that these good people can do that gradually all by themselves without great expenses and that they can bring everthing in the way they desire if the authorities could be moved to
assign them this land.
Now because it was not advisable in this situation to stay on the first project, while on the other hand the opportunity presented by this honest man is known to very few or even none of the present magistrates I requested him to draw up a plan for the 
land mentioned in great confidence and to give more information and to make a report about how he thinks that this matter can be done at its best.  If they might be able to move the Canton of Berne that they will assign to the poor Taufers, what he did not
only promise but he also said that he shortly would make an express trip to Vaud to investigate carefully so that he could make more a complete plan regarding everything in spite of the shortness of the time and the present season.
I from my side will try in the meantime to bring the difficulties introduced concerning the proposed swamps to the Magistrates who are willing to help the Mennonites and to inform others and at the same time to try to move them not only to abstain from 
this project but to approve the plan given by engineer Bodmar and to give this to the Canton in consideration when the time is ripe and to urge the execution of it, so that we may hope that the Magistrate will not oppose.
And while in between the above mentioned festivities and vacations almost come to an end and consequently the matter of the inland poor Mennonites again might be placed on the table.  It will be necessary that we get full information about what you have 
decided concerning a deputation to Berlin and also what already might have been done there or what is the status quo of the affair so that the good friends over here as well as I can take their measures in time accordingly.  the hundred copies of the 
Mennonite Confession of Faith which have been sent out according to my information for Frankfort and Stuttgart but did not yet arrive here I certainly expect about Thursday or Friday.
As far as we could ascertain there has been brough tin the last few days another time some poor Taufers in the  Hospital or Alms house and they have been imprisoned there.  But I will investigate thereabouts and give information accordingly.  I do not doubt
that they will free them as soon as they will hear that they can travel to Prussia so that they can regulate their matters themselves and prepare for the journey.
In grace and favor of the most high and prayers as well as many greetings.
Remaining your willin gservant
To the highly honored Lord 
Johan Ludwig Runckel

Abstract: zich beklagende over vertraging der zaak, vooral door invloed der baljuwen, die niet gaarne de voordeelen missen hun in de vervolging der Doopsgez. verzekerd.  (Fransch).  2 blz. fol. Met 2 bijlagen:

Eng. trans. LMHS
Transcription at HSP (of all -- including a. & b.)
Notes: English summary at LMHS:
Letter from Runckel to Fagel, complaining about the delay of the matter, primarily because of the influence of the bailiffs who are not happy to miss the benefits gained by the persecution of the Mennonites.  2 sheets, with 2 inclosures.
a.  Decision of the great council of the city of Bern, January 28, 1711, regulating the departures of some individual Mennonites, in 7 articles.  4 sheets.
b.  Memorandum from Runckel against the decision presented February 6, 1711 in which he opposes the sending over to the States General of the acknowledgement, in that they are in agreement and according to his thinking are divided.  2 sheets.

<religion>Anabaptist</religion>

Persecution - released from prison
Abstract: zich zeer beklagende over het gedrag van den leeraar Peter Gärber die in weerwil zijner hem gedane beloften zwarigheid maakte om de door de commissie gevorderde belofte af te leggen, waardoor hij zich zelven en de anderen in groot gevaar heeft 
gebracht.  Hij verzoekt dat een bestraffende brief daarover aan Peter gericht worde.  Wederom zijn 15 gevangenen op gelijke voorwaarde losgelaten, zoodat er nu nog 15 benevens den vroeger gebannen Samuel Räber in hechtenis zijn; hij vreest dat ook de 
vroeger gebannen leeraars Daniël Grimm en Schlimann heimelijk zijn teruggekeerd.  Hij denkt eerlang naar Schaffhausen terug te eeren, maar zal zorgen te Bern te zijn tegen het vertrek van de vluchtelingen, blijft de geheele correspondentie in deze zaak
op zich nemen, daar er onder de Doopsg. nauwelijks iemand behalve Daniël Richen daartoe in staat is en geeft eenigen raad omtrent de inrichting en verspreiding eener circulaire, die de commissie aau de Zwitsersche Doopsg. voornemens is te zenden.  7 
blz. fol.
Eng. trans. LMHS
Transcription at HSP (in German)
Notes: English summary at LMHS
From the same to the commission, complaining seriously about the conduct of the minister, Peter Gaerber, who in spite of his pledge made it a matter of conscience to lay aside (?ignore?) the pledge demanded by the commission, through which he brought 
himself and others in great danger.  He requested that a charge be sent by letter to Peter.  But then there were 15 prisoners with similar charges who were released, so that there are now still 15 beside the earlier exiled Samuel Raber who are in 
captivity, he is afraid that also the recently exiled minister Daniel Grimm and Schlimann have returned secretly.  He is thinking before long to go back to Schaffhausen, but there is concern in Bern against the departure of the refugees, but then the 
entire matter remains for him to do, where he recently noticed somebody among the Mennonites other than Daniel Richen who gives advice on the production and spreading of a circular, which the commission is undertaking to send to the Mennonites in 
Switzerland.  7 sheets.
Eng. trans. LMHS:
Berne, Feb. 21, 1711
My very Esteemed Gentlemen:
Due to lack of time and the pressure of business I contented myself to send to you Gentlemen by the last mail a copy of my former mailed relation with the State.  from this copy the Gentlemen will have learned what has happened through the help of hte 
Almighty God.  After much bitter debating in the Taufer Chamber, a good number of the poor Taufers were freed.  It was very close that the Preacher Peter Gärber due to his conscientious scruples would have been imprisoned until the complete departure 
of the rest.  in this connection I will not omit to tell you Gentlemen that this man angered me, not a little.  I was prudent enough to foresee trouble and as a precaution I visited all the imprisioned Taufers a second time in order to tell them that 
before their liberation they would first be obliged to appear before the Tuafer Committee.  There they would needs promise a mouth and hand or with "Yes" and the handshake used here and they must promise to faithfully commply with the orders given to
them.  These orders will consist especially in the following:  must be subject to call during their freedom; must be quiet and especially avoid worship services.  I recognized this preacher immediately, a hotheaded and stubborn fellow and I strongly 
advised him and I begged him even in the Name of God that he should consider the stiuation and try to give a good example to the others so that whether His Majesty or you Gentlemen or myself may appear as liars because it would only complicate the 
situation.  He listens quietly, but what has happened, it is demonstrated that he did not heed the advice, but followed his own whim and will.  Through such a behaviour he only strengthened the opposition of the authorities against his fellow brethren.  I 
am ashamed because I promised bona fide that not the least difficulties would ever occur.  After I had left the Taufer Committee I went home and called all the released Taufers to me.  He impressed upon them the happenings in the Committee and I begged 
them for God and their own sake to behave accordingly, avoiding any reason for complaint by the Government.  All promised me to do this.  I reprimanded the preacher for his misdeed and which endangered him to be imprisoned again and I told him that I would
report to you Gentlemen of all  that transpired.  The only response he gave to me was to beg me to be patient.  Whether the Committee or I are able to trust rightly this man, exspecially I fear that he might again hold meetings and preach despite his 
pledged word.  This would endanger all the Taufers.  For this reason, I humbly beg you Gentlemen to write to this fellow in High German demanding of him.  I would appreciate that letters were sent to me in order to be certain that he will receive it
Last Thursday according to the enclosed list, again 15 of the imprisoned Taufers were released in the same way and same manner as the earlier ones were liberated. Today only 15 besides Samuel Raber are still in prison.  I hope the first 15 will be fully 
freed also as soon as their bail producers and the payment for the expenses are found correct.  The rest must be patient more so because the Committee informed me (in the name of the County) by letters of the 14th and  19th instant that the government has 
learned from reliable sources that besides Samuel Raber there is also a Daniel Grimm and a certain Aschliman, both preachers again reentered the land secretly.  So that we may prevent a measure of danger, I am asked to do everything that such actions 
cease.  It would only vex the already very sensitive government.  I promise to do my utmost and I shall again instruct those who are free to do their share by advising secretly arrived Taufers who previously had been expelled, to leave the land at once.  I
fear very much that in case one of the expelled should be again apprehended, the penalty were excessive.
Last Thursday I recevied your Honorable letter of the 10th inst.  From this I learned that my letters of the 24th and 28th ultra together with the enclosures are in your hands and that all the negotiations made by me have found your obliging acceptance.  
this occasions great joy to me.
In answer to your very friendly demand, I gladly will be at your disposal and I shall not return to Schaffhausen until all in behalf of the poor Taufers has been brought to such a conclusion that for a few months my presence would not be needed.  In 
reality I really should have been at home because my wife had a baby, yet thank god everything was normal and more my eldest son had an accident and other domestic affairs are calling.  In this time they can arrange their affairs and in case there should 
be disputes arising they can be related to me on my return next May and can give the information thereof to the Sovereign asking for a remedy.  I this way all could be solved at once, instead of bothering the authorities for one thing today and another 
thing tomorrow.  Furthermore, it is to be considered that in the first two months less work needs to be done than in the last two.  For this reason I think that for me it is easier to be away now than by waiting until the departure of those poor people.  
thus I would leave an opportunity to look after my own affairs and afterwards I could take care of the Taufer affairs again with a better spirit.  However, if the Gentlemen should desire to get in touch with the fellow believers I then wish you would 
address all to me in Schaffhausen because it would travel surer and quicker through my channel than through anyone else because during my absence I still would be in correspondence with the Taufer Committee and the Taufers themselves.  Among those who were
prisoners there is none able to correspond with you Gentlemen.  There may be some among the dispersed but this I cnanot know, except Daniel Reichen of Fruitigen. However his homestead is so far from the others that I don't believe it possible that during 
the four months of freedom could assemble together, for they want to avoid the arousing of suspicion or jealousy of the authorities.
I am very glad that the Gentlemen will send circular letters to all the Taufers and I have no doubt taht our authorities won't be adverse to them.  Since you Gentlemen honored me with your confidence and will discuss this affair with me I believe the best 
and safest politiy is that this distribution of the circular letters be made through my channel.  This should not be done before the coming May.  It will be convenient that the Gentlemen send the original text to me in the next April and the text should be
in High German.  In this way it could be shown privately to some of the leaders here for eventual amendments.  In this way I could expedite the distribution of quite a large number in the whole country.  In this way the distribution would occur in a wise 
manner.  Expenses would be saved, and the transportation would be spared for the amended letters.  The letter would be more comprehensive for the people, due to the writing of it in the customary manner and lanugage for this land.  Since our Sovereign 
Council decided to print the freedom placard and to give one (copy) to each taufer and tauferin.  It would not only be a great convenience that your circular (morning) letter be in the placard, but I am certain, it would greatly please the authorities 
because it would show that no secret nor treasonable intention is contained therein.  This Honorable Gentlemen, is my candid belief as concerning my trip to Schaffhausen and as well concerning the correspondence and the distributio of the projected 
circular letter.  May I beg you to consider this and later inform me how you feel about everything prior.  I remain your humble servant commending you
Runckel

HSP--German transcription</cc>

Abstract: bericht den stand derzaak vooral nadat hij het besluit der Staten-Generaal van 30 Dec. ontvangen en ingediend heeft, hoopt dat men de zaak niet zal uitstellen tot a ontvangst van en brief uit Pruisen en bericht dat het gedrag van Samuel Räber, 
ee Doopsgez. van 75 jaren, die zijn gegeven woord om nooit in het Bernsche terug te keere.  gebroken had, een zeer ongunstigen invloed heeft gehad; alleen dfoor zijn tusschenkomst is de over hem beraamde doodstraf in levenslange gevangenis veranderd, maar 
het geeft velen aanleiding tot den wensch dat niet één Doopsgez. uit de gevangenis ontslagen worde, eer zij allen te gelijk het land erlaten.  5 blz. met 2 bijlagen.
a.  Brief van Runckel aan de overheid te Bern, tot geleide der missive van de Staten-General, 30 Dec. 1710, waarbij dezen het verzoek der Nederl. Doopsg. ondersteunen.  Hij verwijst tevens naar zijn vroeger Memoriaal.  3 blz. fol.
b. Brief aan den griffier Fagel, 17 Jan. 1711:  hij heeft den brief der Staten-Generaal overhandigd, maar de commissie, die aanvankelijk de zaak met ijver had aangevat, zoekt nu uitstel door eerst een mondgesprk van hem te eischen, eer zij die in den 
grooten raad inbrengt.  3 blz. fol.
Eng. trans. LMHS
Notes: English summary from LMHS:
From Runckel:  Tidings about the affair, above all now that he has received the resolution of the States-General of December 30 and has presented it he is hoping that one would not set the matter aside till after the receipt of a letter from Prussia and 
that news of the conduct of Samuel Raeber, a Mennonite of 75 years, who broke his promise never to return to Bern has had a very unfortunate influence; only through his intervention was the death penalty changed to life imprisonment, but this gives much 
support to the wish that not a single Mennonite should be released from jail, before they all, one and all, leave the land.  5 sheets with enclosures.
a.  Letter from Runckel to the authorities in Bern, to the drafters of the missive from the States-General, of December 30, 1710, in which they support the appeal of the Dutch Mennonites.  At the same time he refers to his former memorandum.  3 pages.
b.  Letter to the clerk Fagel, January 17, 1711:  he has turned over the letter of the States-General, but the Committee, which had untertaken the matter with interest, is now trying to set it aside, first through an interview with him, before bringing it 
before the large council.  3 sheets.

Abstract: over de paspoorten; en over de hardnekkigheid der Reystischen gemeenten; de meening der Amst. commissie, dat zij bevreesd zijn voor kwade trouw bij de regeering heeft geen grond; hij is aan sommige hunner te wille geweest, om zekeren Bernhard

<religion>Anabaptist</religion>

Administration - religious
Diplomatic relations
Economic network - payment
Image - Illustration
Travel network - logistics
Abstract: tot geleide van een memorie die als bijlage volgt:  berust in hun besluit omtrent de Buckenberger Doopsgezinden, acht het beter dat verzachting van de beloften, die de vertrekkenden moeten afleggen, na hunne aankomst in Holland door de diplomatie 
worde bewerkt; heeft de circulaire ontvangen en vertaald, maar acht het beter met den druk nog een weinig te wachten; berust in hun afwijzend besluit op zijn aanbod om zelf het land af te reizen en meldt dat George Ritter het hoofdgeleiderschap aanvaard en
reeds 5 schepen besteld heeft, mits hem twee onderdirecteuren en de bekwaamste uit de Doopsgez. zelven bijstaan.  Geeft nog eenig naricht over D Ricken en de paspoorten, vooral ook over zijn onderhandelingenn zoowel met de Doopsg. zelven als met den raad 
van Ber, ten gevolge zijner memmorie.  8 blz. fol.
Eng. trans. LMHS
Notes: English trans:
Berne, April 25, 1711
Honored and Esteemed:
I have received your letter of 31st ultra.  Due to much work I could not answer earlier, however, I wanted at the same time to study the letter to give you Gentlemen a seasoned and complete reply.  I learned with pleasure that my letters of February 25, 
March 11, 18 were delivered.  I am also pleased to hear that you Gentlemen are agreed completely with all I have done in the taufer episode.  This is new encouragement to me.  I reluctantly have to say concerning the Gaufer committee I have often worked 
with very strange people (I won't say stupid or mischievous people).  they often act to satisfy only the ego, nont even knowing what we really desire.  You will see from the enclosed memorandum how several difficulties have arisen, partially to the 
congregation, partially officialdom and partially to this Committee which should defend and favor them.  I see no other way but to bring my demands again before the Sovereign Council in order to eliminate those difficulties.
Answering point for point to your Honorable Letter, may I tell you that the publication of the freedom decree in the neighborhood had just the effect supposed by you Gentlemen, i.e. those who are still in the land can use the accorded time to bring their 
things in order and those who are in other parts in the Veuenberg lands (then a province of Prussia) firmly estalbished.  I shall send back as soon as they too have ordered their affairs (i.e. sale of belongings).
Concerning the taufers bill in Bachenburg (Solothurn) I leave everything to the intelligent considerations of you Gentlemen.  However, in my heart I fear that these people if they should not leave now would be exposed later to advances and persectuions for
reasons mentioned prior.  I believe they would find no security anywhere it seems that the spirit in this canton is stronger against them than for them.
Concerning the oath which the Taufers and their descendants are supposed to give not to reeenter the land anymore, I suspect that the laudable County will hold for in their demands, whatever argument and witnesses to the contrary.  Nevertheless, I shall do
my best at the opportune time to get the authorities to amend this clause.  i doubt very much that some result might be obtainable now.  I rather believe that once Mr. von St. Saphorin has returned from the Hague, then would be the time to obtain a 
modification (of oath) from the county of Berne through his efforts.  this means that by that time the poor Taufers have already have arrived in Holland.  I don't believe that these peopole will expect anything plausible from St. Saphorin.  I hope that 
there will be no danger for the Mennonites settled in the Neuenberg lands because if the Canton should want them expelled, it would be obliged to issue them a passport.
The circular letter sent to the Taufers here has been translated into High German by me (for written in Swiss dialect).  I have discussed this affair with some gentlemen and as you will see in the enclosed copies my explanations were considered as very 
good except a few passages.  It was concluded that the printing should be delayed until we have the list of the Taufers since the formulation of those lists takes more time than was expected.  I shall send them to the printer next week and immediately 
thereafter the distribution can start.  Then we will elarn what effect this letter will produce.  Since you Gentlemen don't deem it necessary that I travel through the land, I shall forget it.  It will only produce expenses.
After much argumentation Mr. George Ritter finally accepted to lead the Taufer expedition as General Director.  He is willing to work with me to make the necessary preparations.  He however, requries that I furnish two assistant directors for each ship 
who would be selected from the taufers themselves.  These aides would help him in any capacity during the voyage.  We approved all this on the condition that you Gentlemen concur.  He (Ritter) left already for Interlaken in the Bernese Oberland, Mayor, and
will give the necessary orders for the prompt manufacture of the ships in Linsingne.
I ascertained that among those taufers there were about 20 persons skilled in teh science of navigation and ship transportation.  I agreed with Mr. Ritter to place on each ship four of these men who could alternate in pairs, to relieve the strain of those 
who recently are not accustomed to this duty.
Daniel Richen agreed to furnish the budgeted 1000 Rixthallers as needed and I hope that all this is final.  I shall give an account to you gentlemen of all amounts of all finances, the quality, and quantity, in addition to all events enroute.
A passposrt should be issued only in the name of Mr. Ritter which would be valid for 500 to 550 people with their small baggage.  I shall obtain a similar passport from the French authorities.  Since impossible to estimate the definite time of the 
departure of these people, they should get a further extension of two to three months beginning July 1.
I have this announcement in answer to your last letter.  May I still add that my abovementioned Memorandum was read last Monday before the daily council.  Afterwards it was sent to the Taufer Committee wiht the order to examine it at once, to make their 
respective report and return it to the Council and thence to the sovereign Council.  Until now this has not been done, but I expect it will happen next week.
Before I decided to again go before the Sovereign Council I sent two memorandums to the Committee on March 19 and 15 inst.  In these I referre to the difficulties aforementioned and of which I discussed with you.  SInce they declared their "power of 
attorney" is not that for reaching and since I noted that this committee has not yet given up its custom to pester the poor Taufers, I went again before the sovereign council complaining of the same, but wihtout mentioning this chicanery.  In this way 
those Gentlemen have no reason to complain that their tender souls have been irritated.  These Gentlemen have an idea that the Government makes special favors to the Taufers permitting them to travel after they have been dispoiled even to the last drop of 
blood ad instead of helping them, they do all within their powers to produce new hindrances.  They try to produce the impression that neither the Government nor you Gentlemen nor even I were interested in the departure of these people.  they surmise that 
the laudable county of Berne could again produce new obstacles despite its word to the contrary.  In order to amend the clause which permitted the Tauffers to take their belongings with them.  Despite all this I advise these people at every occasion not to
hold too fast to their earthly goods, but to rely on the help of God in order to depart  as soon as possible  their ungrateful fatherland and to look for another land where they would have more peace and freedom of conscience.  One part of the Taufers are 
quite willing but most of them to my regret I must say are unwilling.
Conclusion
Runckel
Research Notes: <cc>Lowry II p874;
LMHS--English translation</cc>

<xn>This letter is significant because in it, it is confirmed that the ships used it the 1711 migration from Switzerland to the Netherlands were built for this purpose. This letter discusses Mr. Ritter going to Interlaken to purchase wooden boards. I also realized in this letter that Galley ships were likely used.--KFD;

Abstract: Waarbij hij in 11 art. aanwijst welke bezwaren er bestaan, waardoor de Doopsg. zich nog niet aanmelden en tegen hun vertrek opzien, met name:  dat de leeraren en diakenen van de amnestie zijn uitgesloten, dat het banvonnis tegen Daniel Ricken niet 
is opgeschort, dat de verdeeling van goederen en eventueele erfrechten tusschen de vertrekkenden en hen die in het land blijven, niet zijn geregeld, dat ten aanzien der kinderen, of zij bij vertrek der ouders kunnen meegaan of moeten achterblijven, niets 
is bepaald, enz. Kopie-Duitsch.  4 blz. fol. met besluit van den raad van Bern, 19 April en 13 Mei 1711, artikelsgewijs beantwoord, meerendeels in gunstigen zin.  Kopie-Duitsch.  4 blz. fol. en extract daarvan, 13 Mei 1711, bevattende de bepalingen 
omtrennt het 6e en 9e artikel (erfrecht en bepaling er het medegaan der kinderen) 2 blz. fol. (Duitsche kopie.)
Eng. trans. LMHS
Notes: Eng. trans:
Agreement
Honored and Very Mighty Gentlemen:
In order to facilitate and hasten the departure of the Swiss Taufers, it is necessary that all difficulties be eliminated which have arisen in the execution of the mandate emanted through the interecession of the Honorable Gentlemen of the States General 
of the United Netherland, His Majesty in Prussia, and you Gentlemen.  In this way it can be expected that this affair so important to the aforementioned powers and the laudable County of Berne would finally come to the desired end.  The undersigned 
Secretary considers it his duty to present the aforesaid difficulties to the Gentlemen of the several states for their respective consideration and eventual amendments.  The aforesaid difficulties consist in the following points:
1.  In the publicized decree there is a clause in Article 2 concerning the preachers and witnesses (Deacons?) which the laudable County should amend.  this clause is confusing for the Taufers, in fact so confusing that they have not come out of hiding.  if
an amendment is made, it should be revealed to the officials concerned.
2.  The undersigned Secretary of Daniel Riechen of Fruittigen thinks it necessary to modify the decree which forbids his reentry.  Otherwise Reichen could not do a good job since he is supposed to come from Holland to meet these Taufers and he would 
furnish all the money needed.
3.  The laudable County of Berne should give the necessary orders to officers (of the Government) eventually also to the Reformed clergy in writing that the following facilities have given for the transportation of the Taufers which may still be hidden in 
the land.  They should be allowed to get their belongings and valuables by themselves or through others, giving them time to bring in all their questions and difficulties.  this will grant me time also to establish the real number of the Taufers for 
transportation and prepare a list of those persons.
4.  The laudable County should also gracefully state that they grant to preachers, deacons (witness bearers) Taufers and Tauferinen, who were legally permanently expelled by the government, the right to recover all their belongings and valuables through 
other persons and also those which may have been deposited with churches by judicial decision.
5.  the laudable County should also declare what should be done in case of a split matrimony, if a Reformed spouse refuses to follow the Taufer spouse and how such spouses should divide their belongings.
6.  How should the departing Taufer parents divide with their children who prefer to remain in Switzerland?  How would an eventual heritance now between departing Taufer parents and their children, left behind, be regulated, if the parents would refuse or 
be unable to pay?
7.  How would this case problem be solved:  If reformed sons or daughters who reached their majority having no parents who would however try to go with their Taufer brothers and sisters and who would wish to take along their man right citizenship rights, 
but you would prohibit it, thus loosing the friendship of the gov ernment (but not man and citizenship rights because reformed).
8.  He shall declare how it would be with the assets of those Bernese Taufer which are still hidden in the land or who previously were seen in Mumpelyard, Alsace, Winschgan, and the Pfalz, in order to prevent their return to the land?
9.  The laudable authority should gracefully concede that rights and assests of Taufer children in their minority should be permitted to be taken along, since these children can't see yet the difference between white or black and all in their behalf is 
happening without their will.  this is only their holy and natural rights.  they should keep all this.
10.  the high authority should also declare that such Taufers should not be prosecuted or punished who had hidden or helped to hide there assets for years.  It is understandable that these people are afraid they will be treated in an unfriendsly way by the
authority or its officials.  It is however, agreed that they would be severely punished if they would be later found guilty of the aforesaid mischief.
11. I hope the laudable authority will soon be able to formulate their wise amendments (to your decree), sending the conclusions in writing to all the officials in whose region still exists Taufer or their assets.  In this way the officials would know how 
to proceed.  At the same time, a detailed copy of the rest to me would be highly appreciated.
The aforesaid demands have as their only purpose that the intentions of hte Gracious Majuesty and the laudable County of Berne be executed easier, speedier, surer, and better.  the undersigned feels sureer that your graceful and merciful orders will be 
followed cheerfully.
With respect
I remain your humble servant
Runckel
April 19, 1711, Berne

Abstract: stelt voor dat hij zelf of een vertrouwd persoon het platte land rondreize om de Doopsg. die zich, in weerwil der amnestie, nog niet aanmelden, op te sporen en tot de afreis te bewegen; voorts dat George Ritter, kruidenier te Bern die de reis naar 
Holland ten vorigen jare gedaan heeft en bij de commissie wel bekend is, de vluchtelingen naar Holland geleide, alles op kosten der commissie.  1 blz. 4o.  
Met bijlage, zijnde een berekening van vermoedelijke onkosten voor den overtocht van 500 Doopsgezinden, met raadgevingen omtrent de aanstelling van een hoofdgeleider en omtrent het emen van paspoorten, tolbrieven enz., onder aanwijzing waarom het ongeraden
is met eenigen schipper een vast accoord voor den overtocht bij wijze van aanneming te sluiten.  5 blz. fol.
Eng. trans. LMHS
Notes: English translation at LMHS:
Berne, March 18, 1711
Since your honored letter of 10th ultra in which you acknowledged the reception of my letters 24 and 28th January,  I did not receive any news from you.  I hope, however, that mine of 18, 21, and 25 ultra as well as the one of March 4 which I directed to 
you Gentlemen may have reached you.  Though a bit belated because of bad and flooded roads, I am confidant also that you'll learn from these letters what had happened from time to time to the poor here residing taufers and how they finally with the help 
and grace of God were liberated and how the publication of the Amnesty has arrived a final and satisfactory conclusion.  you will have seen also what I have done in this episode and I only hope that it will be to athe satisfaction of you HOnorable 
Gentlemen.  From the letter of the 11th instant Gentlemen will have especially learned how in the ame of Good Almighty I resolved to remain here until the whole Taufer affair has been resolved and until all the taufers have departed.
It will be very important to provide in time all the necessary means for the transportation of these good people.  Especially it is necessary to order the construction of ships because in this land there are none able to undertake such a long voyage.  This
report I wanted to send you, Gentlemen, after having taken exact information concerning cost of transportation down the Rhine to Rotterdam, for your wise consideration and so you can take the measures to decide about the needed money.  Since the Taufers 
are scattered throughout the land it is expedient that we ascertain the number of the departing persons so we can order the building of the needed ships and other things.  I consider it important also to convince those Taufers, whom I do not know today 
that they leave Switzerland.  In this help should be given these people by their Captains, their preachers, or other superiors to facilitate the collection of hteir belongings.  to this effect it is possible that I must undertake some excursions into the 
country or else send another confidante to get the best information of everything.  Since such excursions would involve some expense, i wanted to submit this proposition to the judgment of you, Gentlemen, begging you to let me know your decision and in 
case the proposal is accepted, you should provide the wherewithal in thime.  I was in contact with the imprisoned Taufers here, mostly good and simple (common) people.  I became aware that there exists some danger for these people unfamiliar with 
travelling.  I fear that they will experience trouble, provoked by the rough ship crew or even of the directors on the ships or the rough customs house officers or even by money hungry soldiers enroute.  this would not happen if they were under the 
protection of the General direction of a man familiar to the route, a man well recognized as honorable, understanding and brave.  Some money should be in the hands of an honorable man who would provide and order all the necessary items during the voyage.  
He would also fulfill the formalities in the custom houses, present the passports and provide the necessary means at the port of arrival for the poor Mennonites.  He would give you, Gentlemen, a detailed report of all the events during the voyage and an 
account of all the money spent.  I take the liberty to ask you Honorable Gentlemen if you find it convenient that I act in this sense, proposing to you Mr. George Ritter, citizen and grocery store owner of this city, who a year ago accompanied the poor 
deported Mennonites over the same route.  Probably you, Gentlemen, heard of him.  I propose him to you Gentlemen as Director in Chief, promising him refund of all travelling expenses from here to Holland and return.  This Gentlemen to my knowledge is well 
know by Mr. Von Ghend of Rotterdam and By Mr. Jean Jaques Caylle of Amsterdam.  this latter brought Mr. Ritter a year ago in a conference with you Gentlemen and it is quite possible that you will remember him.  If this proposition finds the approval of you
Gentlemen and if Mr. Ritter should be willing to undertake this task we could give him his choice of his ship assistants provided they would be to my satisfaction, so I could recommend them to your approval.
Of the Taufers expelled or still hidden very few came to the fore to my knowledge except Daniel Reichen and his brothers-in-law.  I think, however, that in the near future a greater number shall appear.
Awaiting your reply, I leave, conclusion
Runckel
He then gives a Budget -- see xerox for remainder of translation

Abstract: de amnestie is door geheel Zwitserland en ten gevolge zijner bemoeiing ook in de Palts en aangrenzende landen afgekondigd, hij heeft voor 6 personen het hoofdgeld betaald, daar de 4 anderen het reeds voldaan hadden; er zijn nu nog 4 gevangenen, 
wier borgen man afwacht, met Samuel Räber in hechtenis, die eerst na het vertrek van allen, ontslagen kan worden.  De Pruisische minister heeft van hem verlangd dat hij door zijn invloed de vluchtelingen tot de reis naar Pruisen zou ovoerhalen en na 
zijn weigering pogingen bij de commissie van den raad aangewend.  De koning van Pruisen wacht de gedeputeerden van de Nederl. en Hamburger Doopsg., om over de vestiging de raadplegen.  Runckel is besloten te Bern te blijven wegens de vele moeielijkheden 
die de Doopsg. ondervinden, hij meldt dat er zich 20 of 30 Doopsg. in het kanton Solothurn bevinden, echter zoo nabij het B ernsche gebied, dat het hoogst wenschelijk is dat ook zij tot de reis bsluiten.  ten slotte bericht hij dat nu ook de 3 laatste 
gevangenen zijn los gelaten, vraagt hij ondersteuning van zijn verzoek bij de St. Gen. om nog langer te blijven en vermeldt de gemoedsbezwaren van Daniël Ricken en anderen uit de Ammanische gemeenten tegen de belofte bij hun vertrek af te leggen, 
waarop de commissie wel zal doen in de circulaire te letten.  8 blz. fol.
Eng. trans. LMHS
Notes: English summary at LMHS:
From Runckel; the amnesty is announced in all of Switzerland and its effects are also felt in Palatinate and bordering lands, he has paid the poll tax for 6 persons, while 4 others had already done it, there were now only 4 prisoners, again people 
bought on credit cautiously, with Samuel Raeber in jail, the first after the departure who could be exempted.  The minister of Prussia requested that he by his influence should persuade the refugees to make the trip to Prussia and after his refusal he 
turned his efforts to the commission of the council.  The king of Prussia waited for the deputies from Netherlands and the Hamburg Mennonites in order to discuss the decision.  Runckel has decided to remain in Bern because of the many possibilities that 
are open to the Mennonites, He announces that there are some 20 or 30 Mennonites in the canton of Solothurn, howeer so close to the region of Bern that it is most desireable that they also decide to leave.  Finally he announces that now also the last 3 
prisoners have been freed, so now he asks for consideration of his request to remain longer as presented to the States General, and announces the conscientious scruples of Daniel Ricken and others from there of the Ammanische (Amish) churches against the 
pledge to emigrate, which the commission would do well to recognize in the circulars. 8 sheets.
Research Notes: <cc>Lowry II p776;
LMHS--English translation</cc>

circumstances, the means to be taken on the way, and the decision of the great council that the ones undertaking the trip would have to give up their property, from which the king can percieve more fully.  3 sheets with translation on 2 sheets.

Anabaptists

Abstract: dat van den koning van Pruisen een nieuwe aanbieding is ingekomen, die echter, daar Bern op de oude voorwaarden blijft staan, zeker tot niets zal leiden, waarom hij nogmaals de kolonisatie naar Nederland krachtig aanbeveelt.  4 blz. fol. en 3 blz

Eng. trans. LMHS
Notes: Eng. trans. LMHS:
Berne Nov. 15, 1710
Runckel
Read Nov. 26th
Gist:  The King of Prussia answered that we wanted them to bring all the money they have.  2.  The swiss are to deliver them to the boundaries.  Switzerland says they will deliver only the poor to Frankfurt and the rich must leave their money back.
The fact that Switzerland will have no deputation because Government objection.  Prussia wants a depuation from Holland and Hamburg which the Swiss interpret as subterfuge for time.  The Swiss want to stand on September 26 decisions.  Runckel expects that 
next sumer will be necessary for all deportations.  An answer requested

Secondary Title: Bern, Bern, Switzerland
Publisher: SAA
Date: [12 January 1711]
Type of Work: Correspondence

Custom 1: [1711-01-12]
Custom 4: 1301.02
Keywords: <lang>German</lang>
<religion>Anabaptist</religion>

Administration - religious
Administration - governance
Diplomatic relations
Abstract: bericht den stand derzaak vooral nadat hij het besluit der Staten-Generaal van 30 Dec. ontvangen en ingediend heeft, hoopt dat men de zaak niet zal uitstellen tot a ontvangst van en brief uit Pruisen en bericht dat het gedrag van Samuel Räber, 
ee Doopsgez. van 75 jaren, die zijn gegeven woord om nooit in het Bernsche terug te keere.  gebroken had, een zeer ongunstigen invloed heeft gehad; alleen dfoor zijn tusschenkomst is de over hem beraamde doodstraf in levenslange gevangenis veranderd, maar 
het geeft velen aanleiding tot den wensch dat niet één Doopsgez. uit de gevangenis ontslagen worde, eer zij allen te gelijk het land erlaten.  5 blz. met 2 bijlagen.
a.  Brief van Runckel aan de overheid te Bern, tot geleide der missive van de Staten-General, 30 Dec. 1710, waarbij dezen het verzoek der Nederl. Doopsg. ondersteunen.  Hij verwijst tevens naar zijn vroeger Memoriaal.  3 blz. fol.
b. Brief aan den griffier Fagel, 17 Jan. 1711:  hij heeft den brief der Staten-Generaal overhandigd, maar de commissie, die aanvankelijk de zaak met ijver had aangevat, zoekt nu uitstel door eerst een mondgesprk van hem te eischen, eer zij die in den 
grooten raad inbrengt.  3 blz. fol.
Eng. trans. LMHS
Notes: English summary from LMHS:
From Runckel:  Tidings about the affair, above all now that he has received the resolution of the States-General of December 30 and has presented it he is hoping that one would not set the matter aside till after the receipt of a letter from Prussia and 
that news of the conduct of Samuel Raeber, a Mennonite of 75 years, who broke his promise never to return to Bern has had a very unfortunate influence; only through his intervention was the death penalty changed to life imprisonment, but this gives much 
support to the wish that not a single Mennonite should be released from jail, before they all, one and all, leave the land.  5 sheets with enclosures.
a.  Letter from Runckel to the authorities in Bern, to the drafters of the missive from the States-General, of December 30, 1710, in which they support the appeal of the Dutch Mennonites.  At the same time he refers to his former memorandum.  3 pages.
b.  Letter to the clerk Fagel, January 17, 1711:  he has turned over the letter of the States-General, but the Committee, which had untertaken the matter with interest, is now trying to set it aside, first through an interview with him, before bringing it 
before the large council.  3 sheets.
Research Notes: <cc>LMHS--English translation</cc>

het geeft velen aanleiding tot den wensch dat niet één Doopsgez. uit de gevangenis ontslagen worde, eer zij allen te gelijk het land erlaten.  5 blz. met 2 bijlagen.
a.  Brief van Runckel aan de overheid te Bern, tot geleide der missive van de Staten-General, 30 Dec. 1710, waarbij dezen het verzoek der Nederl. Doopsg. ondersteunen.  Hij verwijst tevens naar zijn vroeger Memoriaal.  3 blz. fol.
b. Brief aan den griffier Fagel, 17 Jan. 1711:  hij heeft den brief der Staten-Generaal overhandigd, maar de commissie, die aanvankelijk de zaak met ijver had aangevat, zoekt nu uitstel door eerst een mondgesprk van hem te eischen, eer zij die in den 
grooten raad inbrengt.  3 blz. fol.
Eng. trans. LMHS
Notes: English summary from LMHS:
From Runckel:  Tidings about the affair, above all now that he has received the resolution of the States-General of December 30 and has presented it he is hoping that one would not set the matter aside till after the receipt of a letter from Prussia and 
that news of the conduct of Samuel Raeber, a Mennonite of 75 years, who broke his promise never to return to Bern has had a very unfortunate influence; only through his intervention was the death penalty changed to life imprisonment, but this gives much 
support to the wish that not a single Mennonite should be released from jail, before they all, one and all, leave the land.  5 sheets with enclosures.
a.  Letter from Runckel to the authorities in Bern, to the drafters of the missive from the States-General, of December 30, 1710, in which they support the appeal of the Dutch Mennonites.  At the same time he refers to his former memorandum.  3 pages.
b.  Letter to the clerk Fagel, January 17, 1711:  he has turned over the letter of the States-General, but the Committee, which had untertaken the matter with interest, is now trying to set it aside, first through an interview with him, before bringing it 
before the large council.  3 sheets.
Research Notes: <cc>Lowry II p634;
LMHS--English translation</cc>

Abstract: met uitvoerig repport hoe hij in twee conferentiën met de commissie al hare bedenkingen weerlegd en gezorgd heeft dat de zaak, die men onder allerlei voorwendsels vertraagde, den 23 Januari in den grooten raad behandeld en nagenoeg geheel naar 
wensch afgedaan is. (Fransch). 11 blz. fol.
dito dito aan de commissee, tot aanmaning om nu ook van de zijde van Nedeland allen voortgang te maken, en tot geleide van den vorige en den volgende.  1 blz. fol.
Van denzelfde an Fagel:  hem is door de commissie het besluit van 23 Januari schriftelijk medegedeeld, men zocht echter nog allerlei exceptiën ten aanzien van den verkoop der goederen, het beperken der amnestie tot degenen die nu gevangen zijn of 
eerlang te voorschijn zullen komen, met uitsluiting der vroeger gebanenen e van de vergunning  ann de Herv. betrekkingen om mede weg te reizen.  Hij heeft daarop zijne tegenedenkingen gemaakt, die in den raad gewogen zullen worden.  (Fransch). 4 blz. fol.
Notes: English summary at LMHS:
Van Runckel to the clerk Fagel, with an exhaustive report about how he in the two conferences with the commission has refuted all their proposals and brought about, that after many delaying pretexts, the matter was brought into the large council on January
23 for discussion, and has been enacted almost entirely as hoped for.  (French) 11 sheets.
The same to the same to the commission, with the plea that from the side of Holland steps be taken to make preogress, and every precaution about the former and the latter.  1 sheet
From the van Runckel to Fagel, with whom the decisions of January 23 have been shared in writing, but one searches for all kinds of exceptions to the application of the sale of property, the restriction of the amnesty to those now in custody or any that 
shall soon come to light, with the exiling of those who were earlier banned, and the restriction of servants to travel along with them.  He has therefore made his counter proposals which are to be considered in the council.  4 sheets.
Research Notes: <cc>Lowry II p672;
LMHS--English summary</cc>

Abstract: zond. datum, in 13 artt. verdeeld, betreffende den armoedigen staat der Doopsgezinden, de redenen van hun afkeer om naar Pruisen te gaan, namelijk de besmetting en de lijfeigenschap, de middelen om die weg te nemen en het beluit van den grooten 
raad dat de vertrekkenden hunne bezittingen specifiek moeten opgeven, waaruit de koning het nadere zien kan.  3 blz. fol. met translaat 2 blz. fol.
Eng. trans. LMHS
Notes: English summary at LMHS:
Copy of the writing of Runckel to the King of Prussia, without date, consisting of 13 articles, concerning the state of poverty of the Mennonites, the reasons for their retraction of the decision to go to Prussia, namely:  the contagion and the life 
circumstances, the means to be taken on the way, and the decision of the great council that the ones undertaking the trip would have to give up their property, from which the king can percieve more fully.  3 sheets with translation on 2 sheets.
Research Notes: <cc>No direct translation, translation of original German is given in Lowry II p712;
LMHS--English summary</cc>

<xn>No date is listed on the actual document. The date instead comes from Documents of Brotherly Love II by Lowry where in a footnote it states that a date "is written in Dutch on the back of one of the papers". However, I do not see where exactly they came to this conclusion--KFD</xn>

Notes: English summary at LMHS:
Letter from Runckel to Fagel, complaining about the delay of the matter, primarily because of the influence of the bailiffs who are not happy to miss the benefits gained by the persecution of the Mennonites.  2 sheets, with 2 inclosures.
a.  Decision of the great council of the city of Bern, January 28, 1711, regulating the departures of some individual Mennonites, in 7 articles.  4 sheets.
b.  Memorandum from Runckel against the decision presented February 6, 1711 in which he opposes the sending over to the States General of the acknowledgement, in that they are in agreement and according to his thinking are divided.  2 sheets.

alles door tusschenkomst van Bernhard Wagner, dien hij tot zijn gemachtigde aanstelt met Ulrich Bärger en Christian Gerber als medehelpers.  4 blz. fol.

Abstract: Van denzelfde: daar hij wegens zijne zaken zich niet te Bern kan ophouden, heeft hij Bernhard Wagner tot zijn gevolmachtigde aangesteld en bij de overheid geaccrediteerd; hij vreest dat het verlange van Melchior Zahlig, om zijne kinderen en zijne goederen te 
krijgen, niet zal worden ingewilligd, omdat zijn kinderen meer dan eens hebben verklaard, niet naar hunnen vader te willen vertrekken.  Het verheugt hem dat de rekeing accoord bevonden is, maar verzoekt uitstel met het saldo.  Het schip dat de Doopsg. naar
Nederland heeft overgebracht, ligt nog te Bazel, maar zal bij verkoop weinig opbrengen, liever wenscht hij het beschikbaar te houden om de Doopsg. over te voeren, die nu te Bern in gevangenis zijn, maar die misschien over eenigen tijd door Bern gaarne zullen losgelaten worden, om van hun onderhoud verder bevrijd te wezen.  Hans Gerber is van de galeien ontsnapt; anderen zijn weêr gevangen geraakt, zoodat het getal gevangenen nu weder 14 beloopt.  5 blz. fol.

Reference Type:  Beiler Documents
Record Number: 73
Author: Rupp, Tieleman, Firnschuss, Hans and Sintznig, Hoppertt
Year: 1710
Title: Neuwied, Rhineland-Palatinate, Germany
Secondary Author: Tellefort, Jasper
Secondary Title: Nieuwendijk, Amsterdam, North Holland, Netherlands
Publisher: SAA
Date: 03 April 1710
Type of Work: Correspondence
Short Title: 565.A Doopsgezinde
Custom 1: 1710-04-03
Custom 4: 1259.01
Keywords: <lang>Dutch; German</lang>
<religion>Anabaptist</religion>

Persecution - expulsion
Persecution - Imprisonment
Movement - international
Abstract: tot geleide van no. 1257.  Twee broeders uit de palts hebben hen bezocht om het verzoek van Jonas nader aan te dringen; de Zwitsersche gevangenen zijn Neuwied onder bedekking vorbij gevaren, waarschijnlijk met bestemming naar Rotterdam; zij dringen
bij de Hollanders aan om hen vrij to koopen. 1p. fol {German, legible}
Eng. Trans. LMHS
Notes: From original:
Jasper Tellefort
Newenwit den 3. April 1710
Sehr Warde en goode friendt benefens u gantze familien alle gute frienden en bekenden sey gewenst hat beste Got seligkeit die orsack om dat wey en u.l. schriven ist desse dat wey teyding uyt die paß heppen gekregen dat die herren von dem 
Schweytzerlandt die dopßgesinde all daer Verfolgen en gefangen Nehmen Nun sint 2 diener von den onse uyt die palß hieein komen dat die Schweytzer Vornehmenß sint om sie naer Hollandt gefang Klickte bringen om aldar an den apgesandten Von berren
zu liefferen haben wier verstanden so haben die balster an unß begert daß wir möchten nach holandt schreiven nun sindt see gesteren den 2 abril hie vorbey gekomen mit 23 gefangenen ohne Weyber und Kinder bey sich zu haben weg geraht der Warren 
25(?) man bey om sie zu bewaren Von den berrener heeren beygestelt ihr? bin mit den 2 balster männer dem schif nach gefarren aber haben mit wol dorffen mit ihnen reden alß wey ein weging mit ihnen geret wolten sie eß niet mehr leyten dat wey 
mit haer sauden sprecken die gefangenen waeren gern hier in die Newewit enß angewest sey wilden dat mit toelatten hat kostlichten böerren dat sey na rotterdam gebracht worden en om dat wey daer geen Kennes hatten heppen wey guet gefunden em an u. 
l. naer amsterdam te schriven en ist unß frindeleyk Versack en u.l. dat gey u. best doc wilt sohn om die leuthen Weder loß te helben die balsser hepen naer hollant geschreven naer wey wetten mit an weine harren elendiger toestandt könt gey in 
den ingelegten briffen sein hie neit goode befohlen verbleybe u. l. dinstwilluge dieners
Thiel Rupp
Hanß Fruschuß?
Hopperecht? sietznig
Newenwit den 3 April 1710
English trans. at LMHS:
Neuwied April 3, 1710
Jassper Tellfort
Very worthy and good friend, beside your entire family, and all good friends and acquaintances, wishing you the very best and salvation.  The reason that we are writing to you is that in time we hope to secure the passports.  The gentlemen from Switzerland
have taken the Doopsgesinnte prisoners and persecuted them.  Now recently two ministers came to us from Palatinate (probably speaking of Offstein, spelled van den onse uyt die palsz) to this place and that the swiss have undertaken to bring them to 
Holland as prisoners.  In order to deal with the people sent from Bern, the people from Boltzen (see the march 15, 1710 letter) sent word to us, so we understood, to ask us to send them on to HOlland.  Now they passed by here on April 2 with twenty-three 
persons aboard as prisoners without having their women and children along in terrible condition.  there were twenty-five men with them to guard them, on orders from the officials in Bern.  Together with the two men from Boltzen I followed the ship but we 
were not allowed to talk with them.  When we talked with them a little bit they did not want to permit it that we talk more with them.  the prisoners would have preferred to come here to us in Neuwied.  They felt that it was an expensive loss to them to be
brought to Rotterdam and now that we knew nothing about it that they were passing by, we found it good to write to you brethren at Amsterdam, and our friendly request is that you, dear brethren, that you might do your best in order to help the people to 
gain their freedom again.  The men of Boltzen would have written to Holland, but we do not know to whom their miseable circumstances in the letters could go and with this we remain, dear brethren, your faithful servants.
Thiel Rupp
Hans Firnschuss
Hoppert Siesznig
Research Notes: <cc>Lowry II p146;
LMHS--English translation</cc>

<xn>BREN -  Combined PDF added alongside the individuals, as they were already present when I began uploading the combined (12/13/23);

Deleted the individual pdfs.(12/11/24)--KFD;

This letter was sent to Nieuwendijk, a street that still exists in Amsterdam. It was sent specifically to Vergulden Fuorn, the golden Fish, ehcih does not appear to exist today.--KFD;

Also, according to the footnote in Documents of Brotherly Love II, this document mixes up Dutch and German at times.--KFD

Excess keywords that might need to be captured in mentions include Swiss, Swiss Refugees, Rotterdam, Holland, Switzerland, Pfalz, Palatinate, Offstein, Boltzen, Firnschuss, Hans, Siesznig, Hoppert</xn>
'File' Attachments: internal-pdf://3261015816/565.A_1259_01.pdf

Amsterdam Ao 1707
Terschooten voor Wynand Bouman, syn huysvrouw & 3 kinderen op de reys naar Pensylvanien door onse vader ? David Rutgers hetwelk door de Diaconen van de waterlantse & vlaemse Gemeente ende de gemeente der Oude Vriesen ons soude worden gerestitueert

11 Apl aan Bouman op syn reyse besd na London  S28 -- 
Door Adam Francken in London betaalt dat hy op ons heeft getrocken voor vertelring aldaar & haar vragth franco in Pensilvania & Kostgelt onder wegen voor jeder persoon comt 8 1/2 L st comt voor Wynand Bouman syn Vrouw & 3 Kindern syn 3 1/2 persoons is 
alsoo 
L30 a 34 s 8 d  S 312 - -
ago 5 1/2 s do     17 3 -

                S 329 3 -
aff de 1/2 voor d'onde vriesen:
                  164.11.8
           ???               S 164.11.8
  Comt voor onse gemeente    S 192.11.8

Wy ondergeschr. bekennen ontfaangen te hebben van de bovengemelde Somme voldaan te syn van de diaconen bovengemeldt
Amsterdam die 11 November 1707
David Rugers Junior
voor reck van d Erfgenamen van myn vader Za
David Rutgers

Business - debt

Economic network -funding
Economic network
Migration - transatlantic
Persecution
Abstract: Van denzelfde (Hendrik Saldenus) aan denz. (Corn. Beets), met opgave van expeditiekosten van het request, bericht dat de Staten-Generaal de aanvragen van Bern en 50 Doopsgez. naar Amerika op Holl. schepen te mogen vervoeren geweigerd en dat de 
prov. staten van Utrecht de zaak der Doopsgezinden bij de Staten-Generaal door een bepaald voorstel ondersteund hebben.  2 blz. 4to
Transcription at HSP
Notes: From transcription at HSP:
Copie
Hage den 24 Maert 1710
Myn heer.
Ik referere my aen myne gedienstige van eergisteren en hebbe verders het plaisis aen UEd te senden de twee gerequireerde Copien authentiq van haer Ho: Mo: resolutie van den 15 laestleden rakende de vervolgde Mennoniten in Switzerland.  Ver ders hebbe ik de
depesche gelden ten comptoire generaal van den Heer Griffier Fagel betaelt tot nu toe bedragende 14. gld. 13 St. ik sal verders aen U Ed alsmede gecomm. van de mennoniten communiceeren wat in die sake sal voorwallen, dogh niet sonder permissie van myn 
meester den heer Fagel Griffier; dog die moet U Ed by avance seggen (met versoek nogthans, het onder UEd te houden) dat de heeren van Bern door haer geauthoriseerde aen Haer H.o. Mo. voorleden saturdagh hebben versogt haer HO: Mo: pasport om uyftigh 
anabatisten door sekere heer Riter, op haer Ho: Mo: schepen na America te mogen senden, dogh haer Ho: Mo: hebben dat versoeck beleeft en met redenen gedeclineert. hebbende die redenen genomen uyt hare vorige brief van voorschryvens waervan gem. heer 
gecommitteerde een copie sol worden gegeven tot narigtinge met versoek om den inhoude van haer Ho: Mo: Brief van voorschryvens te seconderen Morgen sol ik myn werk maken welgens heer grieffier te versoeken my te permitteeren UEd een copie van het antwoord 
van Haar Ho: Mo: aen UEd te mogen senden; soo sulx my gepermitteert werd, sol ik niet manquereen U Ed hetselve toe te senden.  De heeren van de provintie van Utrecht hebben ook getoont het goed gedragh en conduite van de Mennoniten te favoriseeren, door 
dien deselve daarover een propositie in haer Ho: Mo: vergaderingen hebben gedaen.  Ik heb hier niet by te voegen als dat ik gaarne wil en sol vigileren om te vernemen wat verder in UW Ed saken sol voorwallen blyvende
UEd gehoorsame dienaar 
H. Saldenus
Research Notes: <cc>Lowry II p124</cc>

<xn>Further mentions of the plan for movement of Anabaptists to America from Bern in 1763;

Excess keywords that may need to be captured in mentions include States General, Bern, Canton of Bern, Swiss, Swiss Refugees
